summary: This is an internal email from a Chief of the Public Corruption Unit at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, dated April 16, 2019. The sender is requesting information on engagement efforts with a list of previously identified, potentially significant victim witnesses from the Epstein case, based on a review of old FBI 302s and grand jury testimony.

persons.name: Chief Public Corruption Unit
persons.role: Chief, Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: The sender of the email, who is requesting an update on engagement with potential victim witnesses identified from a review of Epstein case documents.

events.title: Internal Inquiry on Victim Witness Engagement
events.description: A Chief in the Public Corruption Unit sends an email inquiring about which previously identified, potentially significant victim witnesses from the Epstein case have been contacted by the office.

keyFacts: The document is an internal email from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, dated April 16, 2019.
The sender had previously reviewed 'old Epstein 302s and grand jury testimony' and identified a list of names as 'potentially significant victim witnesses'.
The criteria for significance included the victim's age and conduct that 'went well beyond massages'.
The email is a follow-up request to determine which of these witnesses have been engaged by the office and to strategize on contacting the others.
The document indicates an active review and investigative effort by the SDNY into the Epstein case in 2019, focusing on victim witnesses.
